snippet.textDisplay:
Yes, I knew little about this movie before I saw it. Still wasn't very good, to me.


This movie is kind of a Parasite.

Here's a movie that should have been nominated and should have won the Oscar:

" The Laundromat "

It's a movie, which feels like a really likable informational video about insurance fraud and tricky money schemes... Lol... Antonio Banderas and Gary Oldman are just so much fun to watch!!! It's a delightful film! Based on a true story, as well, about the Panama Papers.

For me, this beats other movies nominated for movie awards. It's an artwork, turning a boring subject into pure fun, with a unique way to tell a story and make a point as well. The characters have their ups and downs, as well. It's a Steven Soderbergh project (I had thought he retired, so glad he didn't!) and his style lifts the story and turns it into an enjoyable ride that you want to be on.

Okay, I have nothing against "Parasite", but with all the English speaking great movies this year, why did this win so much at the Oscars? It had good directing, great acting, great score, interesting locations and good camera work -- but, I just didn't really believe the story that much. It seemed that the upper class folks were too naive, and the lower class folks were too lucky. Plus, what were the lower class family going to do once they were found out? After all, it was just a matter of time, right? The father of that family seemed to have a higher endurance, in my understanding of the character, but then he goes nuts because he finds out the upper class boss of his isn't fond of his 'smell'? Seriously? This just seems silly to me. I thought he was more humble, and with more grit than to let something like that bother him. Is it realistic that the upper class in South Korea don't check on anyone that they hire? Seems unrealistic to me. So, I really wanted the movie to succeed (for me) by having the characters strike a deal with each other, or reconcile and make an agreement of some kind that brings The 'human experience' to a higher level. But, instead, we got madness, chaos and murder. Wtf? I felt this was a complete cop-out. I'm guessing that this movie may have a more relevant sense to it, culturally, for those from South Korea or living there. Because it may be drawing from a reality, there, that could be worth evaluating more deeply. I thought this was an average movie, because of the story. 5 out of 10. Snowpiercer was more interesting, and better, from this Director.

snippet.textDisplay: (Spoiler alert) 4 out of 5 stars for me, although I generally agree with Kermode's appreciation of this movie. It loses a star for me because the ending felt forced. I thought such a sensitive film would have a more nuanced ending, but it opted for mayhem followed by a hardly credible situation in which the son gets this very long letter from his father - in Morse code, in the middle of a snowy night. That was too much of a stretch for me. But kudos to the cast. And maybe I'll give it a second go, as Mark suggests...
snippet.textOriginal: (Spoiler alert) 4 out of 5 stars for me, although I generally agree with Kermode's appreciation of this movie. It loses a star for me because the ending felt forced. I thought such a sensitive film would have a more nuanced ending, but it opted for mayhem followed by a hardly credible situation in which the son gets this very long letter from his father - in Morse code, in the middle of a snowy night. That was too much of a stretch for me. But kudos to the cast. And maybe I'll give it a second go, as Mark suggests...

snippet.textDisplay:
Are you kidding me? This movie is so average and people talk about it as if its the best thing since The Godfather. I don’t get it.
"Titanicly good", please! Give me a break. The hype around this grossly overrated film is ridiculous. Good movie, don’t get me wrong, it was entertaining, but it is far from perfect and is not a masterpiece at all. Mr. Kermode, get off the bandwagon. And I love Korean Cinema. I loved “Burning”, “The Host”, “The Wailing” and “I Saw the Devil” ( Just to name a few ). So I was expecting to see a great film when I finally saw “Parasite”. It didn’t deliver. And when it’s called “a masterpiece”, or “best film of the decade” I’m astonished (Those aren't Kermode's words, but they are used frequently in other reviews). Did I see some other film called Parasite made in South Korea in 2019? Or maybe I saw a version of Parasite made in an alternate universe? I don’t know, but what I do know is the movie I saw was good, but didn’t come close to being "Shakespearian" or the “masterpiece” that everyone, except me and nine other people, claim it to be.

And when it’s called “a masterpiece”, or “best film of the decade” I’m astonished (Those aren't Kermode's words, but they are used frequently in other reviews). I don’t know, but what I do know is the movie I saw was good, but didn’t come close to being "Shakespearian" or the “masterpiece” that everyone, except me and nine other people, claim it to be.

snippet.textDisplay:
My other close to perfect (last 10 years or so, dons tin hat):
- Birdman
- Winter’s Bone
- Get Out
- Leviathan
- Once Were Brothers
- Ex Machina
- Arrival
- Interstellar (I believe you can be as close to perfect in a particular genre or style and still be deeply flawed 😀)
- Mad Max: Fury Road
- Inside Llewyn Davies
- The Babadook

I’m into unresolved loss and regret.

tldr: who cares 🤣🤣🤣

snippet.textDisplay:
My only problem with the film was the last scene of the son day- dreaming in the basement. Confirming the previous scene of buying the house and reuniting with his dad as a pipe dream and, for me, ruining any ambiguity. I understand that's the theme but it feels on the nose. From art to preach.

I prefer Scorsese's ambigious endings of Taxi Driver and King of Comedy... the meaning of which are purposefully ambiguous but you intuitively figure out the directors intention.

I prefer Scorsese's ambigious endings of Taxi Driver and King of Comedy... the meaning of which are purposefully ambiguous but you intuitively figure out the directors intention.

snippet.textDisplay:
I was disappointed by Parasite, perhaps because of the rave reviews. Hadn't seen a trailer or anything else. Expected a strange and creative film, but it struck me as rather bland and predictable until the third act, when it went off the rails for me. By the last 20 mins, I was bored and waiting for it to wrap it up.

I don't understand the hype for this one, same goes for Knives Out, a totally uninspiring and predictable "mystery".

1917, on the other hand, was a magnificent piece of work, as well as Joker, Uncut Gems and a few others like the Swedish film Grans and Winterbrothers, the Danish/Icelandic production. Far superior films in my opinion.
snippet.textOriginal:
I was disappointed by Parasite, perhaps because of the rave reviews. Hadn't seen a trailer or anything else. Expected a strange and creative film, but it struck me as rather bland and predictable until the third act, when it went off the rails for me. By the last 20 mins, I was bored and waiting for it to wrap it up. 

I don't understand the hype for this one, same goes for Knives Out, a totally uninspiring and predictable "mystery".

1917, on the other hand, was a magnificent piece of work, as well as Joker, Uncut Gems and a few others like the Swedish film Grans and Winterbrothers, the Danish/Icelandic production. Far superior films in my opinion.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a person who watched it last June when it first came out in Korea, no doubt I agree that its a masterpiece.
However, most of the negative reviews i've encountered over the months seem to all stem from the disappointment when the movie didn't live up to the super high expectations created by the overwhelming praise for this movie. There must be a psychological element to it where people switch into a critical mode to highlights parts of the movie that don't suit its reputation as a masterpiece, and lose the enjoyment in the process.
I think it's really most appropriate that this movie is best seen with no foreknowledge, not even non-spoiler reviews. I consider myself really lucky that the only knowledge I had of the film before watching was that it was a Bong joon ho film and it won the grand prize at Cannes.
snippet.textOriginal:
As a person who watched it last June when it first came out in Korea, no doubt I agree that its a masterpiece. 
However, most of the negative reviews i've encountered over the months seem to all stem from the disappointment when the movie didn't live up to the super high expectations created by the overwhelming praise for this movie. There must be a psychological element to it where people switch into a critical mode to highlights parts of the movie that don't suit its reputation as a masterpiece, and lose the enjoyment in the process. 
I think it's really most appropriate that this movie is best seen with no foreknowledge, not even non-spoiler reviews. I consider myself really lucky that the only knowledge I had of the film before watching was that it was a Bong joon ho film and it won the grand prize at Cannes.

snippet.textDisplay: You're right. "It's a Swiss Watch-mechanism" of a movie.  If there's a perfect movie, this is it. Watching the movie once makes you think it's a great fillm;  successive viewings, you're going to say it's a masterpiece. I noticed something new in the second viewing, a different POV in the third viewing and in the 4th viewing. Others are on-point visual cues, others came to me as subtle nuances, preludes to the horror to come. A magnificent film.
snippet.textOriginal: You're right. "It's a Swiss Watch-mechanism" of a movie.  If there's a perfect movie, this is it. Watching the movie once makes you think it's a great fillm;  successive viewings, you're going to say it's a masterpiece. I noticed something new in the second viewing, a different POV in the third viewing and in the 4th viewing. Others are on-point visual cues, others came to me as subtle nuances, preludes to the horror to come. A magnificent film.

snippet.textDisplay: It is a film worthy of the Best Screenplay BAFTA and hopefully the Best Screenplay Oscar and beyond. I saw the live Q and A screening and the host who introduced it said that even though it’s a foreign film, it definitely reminds you of the joy and wonder of the cinema experience and I wholeheartedly agree. It is a film you must see once and I would love to see it again in black and white.
snippet.textOriginal: It is a film worthy of the Best Screenplay BAFTA and hopefully the Best Screenplay Oscar and beyond. I saw the live Q and A screening and the host who introduced it said that even though it’s a foreign film, it definitely reminds you of the joy and wonder of the cinema experience and I wholeheartedly agree. It is a film you must see once and I would love to see it again in black and white.

But it's foreign, has subtitles and stars Asian people Americans don't know, so....
